intro: Geum aleppicum subvar. rugosum, commonly known as the Alpine avens, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Europe and Asia. It features hairy, upright stems that bear alternate, palmately lobed leaves with a distinctive rough texture. The plant produces clusters of small, yellowish-orange flowers with five petals, blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained, rocky or sandy soils and is often found in alpine meadows and forest edges. Due to its ornamental value and hardy nature, it is cultivated in gardens for its attractive foliage and flowers.
